Lilah is an inspiring young woman. The foster youth system is often very difficult on young people. We should be doing more to improve the system to ensure young people have the tools they need to reach their potential.

Today I joined with Rep. Mark Pocan to launch the Congressional Public Education Caucus and stand up for America’s public schools. Millions of students across this country rely on public education as a path to a brighter future. We cannot abandon them and we cannot reverse the progress of the last eight years.    Our first mission is to send the Senate a clear message: they should reject the nomination of Betsy DeVos as the next Secretary of Education.

At the very minimum, the American people deserve a president who can be trusted to put the country’s interests first. The steps President-elect Trump announced today to avoid conflicts of interest are “wholly inadequate,” according to the Department of Government Ethics.    Before he takes office next Friday, the president-elect should release a full accounting of his financial holdings along with a plan to meaningfully avoid conflicts that could cloud his judgement. Anything less will cast a shadow over his presidency.
Stunning report from the nonpartisan Center on Budget and Policy Priorities: Repealing the Affordable Care Act would provide America's richest 400 families with a $2.8 billion tax cut.
Dr. King assured us that the arc of moral history bends toward justice, but only if we stand up and speak out for what is right. #MLKDAY

My Democratic colleagues and I have repeatedly warned about the cost of repealing the Affordable Care Act without an adequate replacement. Yesterday, the Congressional Budget Office put a number to it.   Repealing the ACA would result in 32 million people losing health insurance and would double the price of insurance premiums within a decade. Before Republicans take even one more vote on Obamacare repeal, they need to show us and the American people their plan to replace it.
I will not be attending the inauguration tomorrow. I wrote this letter to my constituents to explain why.

Today, in cities across America and around the world, millions of people stood up for the principle of respect and justice for all. I was so incredibly proud to join the march in Riverside and to witness the unity and passion for equality in our community.   Thank you to all those who participated for reminding the world that America is still a place that believes every person is worthy of freedom and dignity.

Two days after millions of women marched for equality, President Trump signed an executive order reinstating the “global gag rule,” which prohibits sending aid to any foreign organization that provides abortion services or advocacy, even if its done with non-U.S. funds. This move will deprive vulnerable women around the world of medical care they desperately need. It is wrong and this picture is part of the problem.    That’s a lot of “Y” chromosomes.

By refusing to disclose and avoid conflicts of interest, President Trump is threatening to erode the American people’s basic faith in the integrity of our government. I introduced an amendment today that would prevent the Education and the Workforce Committee from passing any legislation that would result in direct financial benefits to the president or one of his companies.   I’m disappointed but not surprised to report that the Republican majority on the Committee voted it down.

President Trump's executive order on immigration, which calls for a wall on our southern border and targets sanctuary cities, is inhumane, wasteful, and unconstitutional. He is advancing policies grounded in ignorance and xenophobia.   This does not reflect who we are as Americans.

President Trump’s executive order turns America’s back to the suffering of thousands of men, women, and children fleeing unspeakable violence.   On its own, this marks a terrible moment for our country and a stain on our legacy. But for President Trump to sign this order on International Holocaust Remembrance Day is an insult to the memories of the Jewish refugees who were murdered when too few nations stepped up to shelter them.
Demonstration at LAX
Demonstration at LAX

Today I spoke on the House floor to honor Fred Korematsu Day and to warn my colleagues that silence and complicity in the face of discrimination is never acceptable. It was shameful in 1942 and it is shameful today. We must always uphold the American principle of liberty and justice for all.

I am honored to be elected Vice Ranking Member of the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs for the 115th Congress. I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure that America’s veterans receive the care and support they have earned.

In selecting Jerry Falwell Jr. to lead a White House panel on higher education reform, the Trump administration is continuing its pattern of appointing bigoted and unqualified people to determine the future of America’s education system.

Some light reading while we await the vote on Devos: this morning I released my Progressive K-12 Education Agenda. It stresses a commitment to public education, expanded access to early childhood education, and equal support and opportunities for low-income students.   https://takano.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/on-day-of-devos-confirmation-vote-rep-takano-releases-progressive-k-12-education-agenda

President Trump’s travel ban targeting seven Muslim-majority countries violates the constitution and undermines America’s moral authority in the world. But its impact hits much closer to home.    An Iranian oncologist granted a visa for "extraordinary ability or achievement” was to start seeing cancer patients in San Bernardino today. Instead, he is stuck in Iran.
Thank you to the 9th Circuit Court for standing up to intimidation and upholding our Constitution.
My mom was put in an internment camp as a child. She is now a small business owner and her son is a United States Congressman. #ShePersisted #ThanksMom

The resignation of National Security Adviser Mike Flynn raises more serious questions about the integrity and competence of the Trump Administration.   It is profoundly alarming that Mr. Flynn was allowed to stay in his position for weeks after it was clear he misled the White House and the public about his conversations with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak. In the end, it was media reports and public pressure, not the irresponsible and possibly illegal interactions with the Russian government, that forced Mr. Flynn’s resignation.   The reckless and opaque approach to national security demonstrated by this Administration is dangerous and unacceptable. This incident should trigger a rigorous independent investigation into the Trump administration’s relationship with Russia.

The Secretary of the Department of Labor is supposed to be the leading advocate for America's workers. There is simply no way that Andy Puzder is qualified to fill that role.   In his two decades as the CEO of a fast food giant, Puzder has faced numerous complaints of wage theft, workplace discrimination, and unsafe working conditions. He also opposes raising the minimum wage and opposes restoring overtime protections to millions of middle class workers.   At the very least, the Labor Secretary should believe in the mission of the agency…and Andy Puzder does not. The Senate should reject his nomination.
Thank you to the many students and teachers who participated in the Valentines for Vets project. And, most of all, thank you to those who serve!

Yesterday, Dr. David Shulkin was sworn in as the next Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Despite my profound frustration with President Trump and the Republican Congress, Democrats and Republicans must put aside our differences and come together to provide veterans the care they deserve.   I look forward to working with Dr. Shulkin to build on the progress the VA has made over the past two years and fulfill our responsibility to support the men and women who serve.

As a teacher, I quickly learned that students succeed when they feel comfortable and respected in the classroom. It is clear that the Trump administration has not learned that lesson.   Subjecting transgender students to bullying and discrimination is a cruel act that shows President Trump is no friend of the LGBT community.

Looking for a little motivation this Monday morning? Read the amazing story of Perris Union High School District's Joseph Williams. He has always been creative and relentless. Now he’s recognized as one of Education Week’s Leaders to Learn From.

My thoughts this morning are with those killed and injured in last night’s tragic plane crash. I am incredibly grateful to the first responders and firefighters, including Riverside Fire Chief Michael Moore, for their tireless and heroic work during a very difficult situation.

My guest tonight for President Trump’s address to Congress is local Muslim activist Fauzia Rizvi. Fauzia is a strong and important voice in our community who works tirelessly to bridge the cultural divides that continue to afflict our country.  I hope her presence is a reminder to President Trump that freedom and respect for people of all faiths is one of America’s founding principles.
My view of President Trump's speech tonight: A new tone but the same dishonesty.

If you subscribe to a service online with one click, you should be able to cancel it with one click. I introduced a bill to prevent companies from trapping people into monthly charges for services they no longer want. I call it the Unsubscribe Act.

As America’s top law enforcement officer, the honesty and integrity of the U.S. Attorney General is held to the highest standard. By lying under oath in a Senate confirmation hearing, Attorney General Jeff Sessions has fallen well short of that standard.    This morning I called on him to resign.

The revelation that Attorney General Jeff Sessions lied in his Senate confirmation hearing makes him the fourth Trump cabinet nominee to do so. The number of false statements being made to Senate committees is extremely disturbing.   Regardless of whether you support President Trump's policies or not, we can all agree that honesty and integrity is a standard all cabinet secretaries must meet.

The details of President Trump’s updated travel ban may have changed, but the harm it does to America’s safety and our standing around the world remains the same. Like the original, this executive order sends a terrible message to our allies while giving our enemies new evidence that America is incapable of differentiating between extremists and the billions of peaceful Muslims living at home and abroad.  It is cruel, it is discriminatory, and it makes America less safe.

There was big news at last night's House Veterans Affairs Committee hearing: The VA will now start offering mental health services to veterans with other-than-honorable dismissals.   This is an important change that I've repeatedly supported to address the crisis of veteran suicide. I am grateful to VA Secretary Dr. David Shulkin and his staff for ensuring that more veterans have access to the care they need.
The health of our society, the reach of our prosperity, and our commitment to equality are all defined by our respect for women. #InternationalWomensDay

Here's what we know about the GOP health care plan: It will cut taxes for the wealthiest people in America, shift costs to low-income families and seniors, and restrict women's access to care.   What we don't know yet is how much it will cost and how many people will lose insurance. I called on my Republican colleagues to stop ramming their bill through Congress without knowing what it will do and who it will hurt.

Today's report from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office confirms the harm that the Republican health care plan would inflict on families across the country.   Under their plan:  - 24 MILLION fewer people would be insured by 2026 - $880 BILLION would be cut from Medicaid - Premiums would rise 20% by 2018.   This is simply unacceptable. I continue to strongly oppose the Republican plan and advocate for building on the progress we've made under the Affordable Care Act.

President Trump made several promises about health care during his campaign. Does the GOP health care plan keep those promises? Earlier this week, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office gave us the answer.
The real March Madness: In the Republican health plan, the wealthiest always win.

Today’s hearing with FBI Director James Comey and NSA Director Mike Rogers confirmed two things.   First, President Trump’s accusation that President Obama wiretapped his phones has no basis in fact. Second, we need an independent, nonpartisan investigation to fully understand the relationship between the Russian government and the Trump administration.   There are several outstanding questions about President Trump’s connection to Russia, a hostile nation that is actively seeking to undermine our democracy. The American people deserve answers to those questions.

The pitch President Trump made to House Republicans this morning exemplifies the problem with their health care bill: It’s focused on winning a political victory, not the health and financial security of the 24 million Americans who would lose health insurance under the GOP plan.
Happening NOW: I’m standing with Sen. Duckworth and veterans across America to oppose the American Health Care Act and the harm it will cause to those who have served.

On the 7th Anniversary of the Affordable Care Act, let’s remember that 97,000 people in our community have health insurance today because of the law. Congress should be working to make health care more affordable and expand coverage to more people, but the American Health Care Act accomplishes neither of these goals.  In fact, it threatens the incredible progress we’ve made over the past 7 years.   I’m standing with my Democratic colleagues to protect the Affordable Care Act and to ensure our family, friends, and neighbors have access to the care they need.
Breaking: Speaker Ryan just pulled the American Health Care Act from the House floor. Here's why that's a victory for the American people.

Thank you so much to all those who came out for yesterday's town hall meeting on health care. Partly because you and so many others around the country made your voices heard this past week, the Affordable Care Act remains the law of the land.   Now we must focus on improving the law to make health care more affordable and more accessible for all Americans.

Today, House Republicans sided with corporations over consumers by passing a resolution that strips your right to privacy on the internet. If signed into law, the resolution means internet service providers will be able to sell your personal information, internet browsing history, and other private data without your knowledge. It also absolves them of their responsibility to take reasonable steps to protect your information.  This is a clear example of special interests winning at the expense of the American people.

Happening Now: I’m standing with the science community and demanding that the House Science Committee recognize the overwhelming evidence that human activity is transforming our planet in ways that could forever cripple our way of life.
Thank you to the millions of Americans, including my uncle, who served in the Vietnam War. Many never received the gratitude they deserved. #VietnamVeteransDay

Today I joined bipartisan calls for Chairman Nunes to recuse himself from the House Intelligence Committee’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.   I do not take this position lightly. Unfortunately, the Chairman’s bizarre covert actions over the past week have undermined the integrity of the investigation and the public’s trust in its findings. It is time to establish an independent commission that can follow the facts wherever they lead. This is what the American people want and this is what the American people deserve.

The Department of Health and Human Service, which is charged with implementing the Affordable Care Act, is using its official website to undermine the law. The Trump administration’s plan is clear: Sabotage the Affordable Care Act for political gain no matter how many families it hurts. This language is false, it is propaganda, and it should be taken down immediately.
Today I join my fellow Californians in celebrating Cesar Chavez Day! He fought radical exploitation with radical activism. #SiSePuede #BadHombre

Over the weekend I joined MSNBC to call for the creation of an independent commission to investigate the connections between the Trump campaign and Russia. Vladimir Putin's effort to influence the 2016 election was a direct attack on our democracy. The American people deserve a thorough and nonpartisan investigation that will follow the facts wherever they lead.

In America, in 2017, it is still legal for a gay employee to get married on Saturday, post pictures to Facebook on Sunday, and be fired on Monday based on only the discovery of his sexual orientation. Today's 7th Circuit Court decision is a major step toward changing that.   This is a victory for equality and a reminder that America is capable of living up to the promise of liberty and justice for all.

When for-profit schools close, student veterans are often left with incomplete and non-transferable credits and without critical housing and food benefits. In response to the wave of for-profit school closures in our region and across the country, I introduced legislation today that would protect student veterans if their school shuts down abruptly.  The bill gives the Department of Veterans Affairs authority to restore GI Bill benefits to veterans affected by a sudden school closure. It’s also allows VA to extend certain benefits, like housing stipends, on a temporary basis to give student veterans time to find a new school.   I look forward to working with Democrats and Republicans to ensure veterans receive the education they deserve.
I'm stunned and horrified that San Bernardino has once again been struck by gun violence. My thoughts are with all those affected by the tragic shooting at North Park Elementary.

I’m always impressed and inspired by the passion students bring to school every day. My visits to Loma Vista Middle School and Arlanza Elementary School today were no exception. Some of them know more about the U.S. Constitution than my colleagues…

It’s my pleasure to announce the winner of the CA41 High School Congressional Art Competition is Sofia Goebel! Her work will be on display in the U.S. Capitol for the next year.    Sofia and her award-winning piece are pictured here along with her teacher, Renee Brandenburg, and Dennis Deets, the principal of Riverside Virtual High School.    Congratulations to Sofia and thank you to the many talented students who participated!
Wishing you and your family a happy and peaceful Easter!

President Trump is the first president in four decades to refuse to release his tax returns. Congressional Democrats and more than a dozen Republicans agree: It is time for the president to deliver on the transparency he promised during his campaign.    It would be a mistake for Congress to move forward on tax reform without knowing how it would affect the Trump family’s business empire.

Juan Manuel Montes came to America when he was just 9 years old and qualified as a DREAMer under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. He was deported anyway after a random stop in Southern California earlier this year.   Deporting young people who call America home is not just cruel, it breaks the promise President Trump made not to target DREAMers.

As Republicans plan another rushed attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act, this new report from the Urban Institute is worth reading. It found that between 2013-2015 the uninsured rate for America’s veterans fell by 40% under the ACA.
Happy Earth Day! Let us never forget our obligation to protect this planet and our privilege to appreciate its beauty.

What frightens me most about President Trump’s foreign policy is that he often does not take the time to understand complex issues. This admission – that he startled our friends and allies around the world out of ignorance – is a prime example of him speaking about sensitive issues without the required expertise.

This morning the Education and the Workforce Committee will consider a bill that gives employers new rights to deny workers overtime pay in exchange for a false promise of comp time in the future. My Republican colleagues call this "flexibility," but I call it yet another way to take leverage away from workers and rig the rules of the economy against working families.   Here's what I said about the bill at a recent hearing...

When for-profit colleges abruptly close, like Corinthian Colleges and ITT Technical Institute, student veterans are often left with incomplete and non-transferable credits and without critical housing and food benefits.  Earlier this month I introduced a bill that would restore those benefits to student veterans, so they can get the education they earned through their service and sacrifice.
Our budget reveals our values. The $25 billion President Trump demands for his useless wall could build enough homes to shelter every homeless family in America.

The Trump administration may disregard the Constitution (particularly the Emoluments Clause) but thankfully our justice system does not. I applaud this decision, which will allow communities to choose the public safety and law enforcement strategies that they find humane and effective.
This is one of the many reasons I oppose the American Health Care Act.

Starting NOW: The Constituent Services Fair is your opportunity to learn about the support and services available to you! Stop by to speak with local officials about VA benefits, tax services, resources from the City of Riverside, and more.

Today is Workers Memorial Day, a time dedicated to honoring those who have been injured or killed on the job. This morning I sat with families who lost loved ones to preventable workplace accidents and listened to their heartbreaking and frustrating stories.   I am more committed than ever to strengthening our workplace safety laws. Every worker deserves a safe environment that allows them to go home to their families at the end of their shift.
This should be at the top of Secretary Betsy DeVos’s reading list: Her own Department of Education found that a federally funded D.C. voucher program produced lower test scores than public schools.

Thank you to the hundreds of Riverside residents who marched today to support the rights of workers and immigrants. When we unite behind the causes of economic mobility, social equality, and respect for every person in our community, we become a safer and stronger country.

The Republican health care bill would strip access to affordable care from 24 million Americans. In many states it would leave seniors and those with pre-existing conditions with no affordable options. It would steal $880 billion from Medicaid. And it would jeopardize access to health care for up to 7 million veterans who could be considered ineligible for the law's tax credits.   Despite these facts, despite overwhelming opposition from nearly every major health advocacy group, despite overwhelming opposition from the American people, and without waiting for the Congressional Budget Office to tell us how much this bill would cost, House Republicans have scheduled a vote on their bill tomorrow.   I could not imagine a more reckless process or a more shameful product. The Affordable Care Act cut the uninsured rate in our community in half and I will continue to defend the progress we've made.

Just now I stood on the House floor and read the part of the American Health Care Act that jeopardizes veterans' access to tax credits for health care. This isn’t about fearmongering or politics, this is about the text of the bill we are voting on today. All I did is read it aloud to my colleagues.

The intentional consequences of the Republican health care bill are bad enough, but the rushed process to pass the American Health Care Act led to serious errors that were entirely preventable.   As I repeatedly warned my colleagues, 7 million veterans could be denied access to the bill’s tax credits because of a loophole that wasn’t closed. This is what happens when you finish writing a bill less than 24 hours before voting on it.

President Trump's firing of FBI Director Comey is an abuse of power that raises several serious questions about his relationship with the Russian government.   It is time for bipartisanship and it is time for an independent prosecutor. The integrity of our democracy is at stake.

A memo written by James Comey after a meeting with President Trump states that the President asked the then-FBI Director to abandon his investigation into National Security Advisor Michael Flynn. The American people deserve to know the truth about connections between Trump's team and Russia. It is time for a special prosecutor.

When I speak to groups of young people, I am often asked what inspired me to seek elected office. In response, I tell them about how as a boy I sat with my grandfather and watched the television broadcasts of the Watergate hearings. I remember being deeply impressed by Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas and how she calmly laid out her case regarding the crimes of Richard Nixon. She spoke about the protections and rights offered to every American by our Constitution, how those rights had long been denied to people like her, and why her faith in that Constitution endured despite those hardships. Her opening statement was a rallying cry to people across America to stand up for our Constitution and our system of government. The news of this last week has kept Representative Jordan in my thoughts, and I hope we can all take her words to heart.

Make no mistake: cutting Medicaid means undermining essential health care coverage for nearly 2 million American veterans. An untold success of the Affordable Care Act has been a sharp increase in the number of veterans receiving care through expanded Medicaid. As of 2015, more than 180,000 veterans in California alone were covered by Medicaid, where 28% more veterans are now enrolled in the expanded program. The Trump plan to slash funding for Medicaid, included in the budget released today, and Republican efforts rollback its expansion would mean that millions of people across America, including many veterans, would lose their access to lifesaving care. This is just one more reason why I voted against the Republican plan to dismantle the ACA, will oppose the budget released by the President, and continue to fight to protect and improve our health care system.

Next Wednesday, May 31, I’ll be holding a Town Hall Meeting at Jurupa Valley High School. I look forward to hearing your questions and thoughts on the issues that are important to you. Please click below to register!

So #TrumpCare 3.0 will still cause 23 million Americans to lose their health insurance by 2026, including 14 million by the end of next year. No wonder the Republicans rushed to pass it before the #CBO score could come back.   This bill isn’t about helping American families, it’s a massive tax cut for the wealthiest Americans paid for by taking health insurance away from those who need it most.

Today I join Americans in our community, across the country, and around the world in somber celebration of Memorial Day. May we never forget those who made the ultimate sacrifice to defend this nation and the ideas it represents.

According to NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Earth’s surface temperature in 2016 was the warmest in recorded history. It was the third year in a row to set a new record, and now 16 of the 17 warmest years on record have occurred since 2001.   Ignoring science and isolating ourselves from our allies around the world will not change these facts. For the sake of our economy, our security, and the future of our planet, I hope President Trump will reconsider this decision.

Withdrawing the United States from the Paris Agreement damages our credibility with allies and further jeopardizes the future of our planet. The president claims to follow a doctrine of “America First” but this is yet another decision that will hurt Americans now and for generations to come.

Every LGBT Pride Month is meaningful but the recent attacks on the LGBT community – both physical and political – give Pride Month 2017 a special significance. In this time of divisiveness and disunity, we have an opportunity and the responsibility to unite behind the principles of justice and equality for all. I wish everyone here and around the world a happy, safe, and meaningful Pride Month.

The nominations of Defense Secretary James Mattis and national security adviser H.R. McMaster were once viewed as a strong and important check on President Trump’s most reckless and ill-informed foreign policy ideas. But last week, acting against the advice and without the knowledge of his national security team, President Trump refused to reaffirm America’s commitment to defend our NATO allies against Russian aggression.    This story reveals that even the president’s experienced national security team cannot protect us from his most dangerous impulses.

Seventy-three years ago today, 160,000 Allied troops landed on the beaches in Normandy to fight one the most significant battles in American history.   This morning I joined Got Your 6 and dozens of volunteers to honor their service and sacrifice by cleaning and beautifying the National World War II Memorial on the National Mall.

In this time of global instability we must work closely with our friends and allies who share our commitment to freedom and democracy. I’m honored to join the Japanese-U.S. Friendship Commission and I’m eager to strengthen our relationship in ways that will benefit America's economy and security.

In 2008, Wall Street’s reckless and unethical behavior triggered the Great Recession and forced a massive taxpayer bailout of financial institutions. This afternoon my Republican colleagues ignored the lessons of that crisis and voted to deregulate Wall Street.   It’s been just nine years since taxpayers bailed out the big banks. If this bill becomes law, it won’t be long until we are forced to do it again.

Pride Month is a time to celebrate every person’s right to be respected and protected under the law. Today I marched with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi and thousands of others in support of civil rights and equality for all.
Watch LIVE: My address to the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) on the meaning of Pride Month and the importance of respect and equality to our military readiness.

This morning the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals refused to reinstate President Trump’s second attempt at a Muslim ban. Their reasoning reflects two familiar themes of the Trump presidency: The Court found the president did not have sufficient reasoning for his actions, and the Court used his tweets as evidence that the ban was not grounded in facts.

One year ago, during a month dedicated to the celebration of diversity and equality, an attack targeting the LGBT community took the lives of 49 people. Today we honor their memories and comfort the families and friends who continue to grieve.    Pride Month is an opportunity to hail our progress toward equal rights and revel in the freedom to be who we are. But it also a time to remember those who have died because they were different – in Orlando, at Stonewall, and in cities and town across the country. We will never forget them.

This afternoon I spoke on the House floor in support of legislation that will strengthen accountability at the Department of Veterans Affairs while maintaining the due process rights of VA employees and protecting whistleblowers. The House passed the bill on a bipartisan basis shortly afterwards.   This was not a perfect bill, but it will give veterans greater confidence that the VA is prepared to meet their needs, and it will allow us to shift our focus to attracting, training, and retaining an exceptional VA workforce.

With all that’s going on in Washington, it can be difficult to track when the House votes on important issues. To help, I’m introducing Vote Alerts to make sure that – whether you agree or disagree – you know where I stand.   Today, I voted for the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act. It will help build a culture of excellence at the VA, support employees who report misconduct, and protect VA employees’ constitutional right to due process.

I am stunned and saddened by the shooting just outside Washington, D.C. this morning. Speaker Ryan and I have our share of disagreements but today he was absolutely right. We are a family, and an attack on one of us is an attack on all of us.   Words cannot express my gratitude for the heroism demonstrated by Capitol Police officers today and every day. My thoughts and prayers are with Congressman Steve Scalise and all those injured in this morning’s attack.

Throughout the debate over the American Health Care Act, I repeatedly alerted my colleagues to a loophole that could jeopardize access to affordable insurance for 7 million veterans. I am pleased to say that the House passed a fix today, but the story of how we got here and what it says about the AHCA should be concerning to all Americans.

Today the House on Representatives began to answer one of the questions posed by yesterday’s tragedy: Can we vigorously and publicly debate our ideas, without shedding our humanity or our respect for each other.   I took to the Floor to offer my prayers for Congressman Steve Scalise and his family, but also expressed my serious concerns with the American Health Care Act and its consequences for American families. Compassion and honest debate are not competing ideas, and we must encourage both if we are going to move our nation forward.

I am incredibly proud to congratulate the students from Sierra Middle School who represented California in a National History Day competition. They won third place for their project on Ruby Bridges, the courageous young girl who desegregated William Frantz Elementary School in New Orleans in 1960.     It was a pleasure to meet these impressive young scholars and I thank them for representing our community and our state so well!

Today we join the U.S. Navy and all Americans in mourning the loss of the seven sailors killed in a collision off the coast of Japan this weekend. My thoughts and my deepest sympathies are with their families at this difficult time.   We also must honor the crew of the USS Fitzgerald, which showed tremendous courage and skill in keeping the ship afloat and preventing many more casualties.
On June 19, we celebrate the end of slavery and remember that – for many years of our history – the independence and freedom we celebrate on July 4th was not available to every American. #Juneteenth

According to the UN Refugee Agency, there are currently more than 65.6 million displaced people, refugees, and asylum seekers fleeing violence and persecution in every region of the world. More than half of the world’s refugees are children.   I support the congressional resolution reaffirming our commitment to helping refugees and displaced persons, and I will continue to support America's role in protecting the world’s most vulnerable people. #WorldRefugeeDay

Abusive scheduling practices make it nearly impossible for working families to create a budget, arrange child care, or plan for the future. Today I joined Rep. Rosa DeLauro and U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren to support the Schedules that Work Act, which would provide workers the certainty they need to care for themselves and their families.

I support the Maker Movement because it enhances education, encourages innovation, and supports small businesses. This week, during the National Week of Making, I introduced the MORE Makerspaces Act to help turn vacant federal buildings into community spaces where young people can learn through hands-on activities and entrepreneurs can access new tools and technology.

When it comes to the health care debate, our community has more at stake than almost any other. The Affordable Care Act led to a dramatic decline in Riverside’s uninsured rate. In fact, our uninsured rate recorded the 10th biggest drop in the entire country.   I will continue working to make sure the newly insured can keep their insurance, and to ensure that all Americans have access to more affordable coverage.

Is the Affordable Care Act perfect? Of course not. Should it be updated so health care is more accessible and more affordable? Absolutely.    But every time someone says "Obamacare is failing” I want them to meet the nearly 100,000 people in our community who have health insurance because of the Affordable Care Act.

Despite President Trump’s promise to protect Medicaid, both the House and Senate health care bills include massive cuts that essentially end the program as we know it.   Who would suffer as a result? The elderly, the poor, children, and the 1.75 million veterans currently using Medicaid.
It was a privilege to join Muslim-Americans at the Perris Islamic Center this morning for Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of Ramadan.   Eid Mubarak to all those celebrating here and across America.

In this time of hyper-partisanship, I understand that the things Democrats are saying about the Senate GOP health care bill can be viewed skeptically by more conservative voters in our community and across the country. But now it’s Republicans themselves who are warning that the process for writing the Senate bill was deeply flawed and the bill will not do what its authors are promising.   So, even if you don’t believe what the CBO says, or what patient advocates and doctors say, or even what I say about the bill, these Republicans should give you serious concerns about what the Senate bill will do to our health care system.

- 15 million fewer Americans insured by 2018 - 22 million fewer insured by 2026 - $772 billion cut from Medicaid   The report released by the Congressional Budget Office today confirms the ugly truth about the Senate Republican health care bill: It is a profound moral failure.
Listen in to my conversation with Vernita Todd at Health Center Partners of Southern California about how the Senate GOP bill would impact health care in the Inland Empire.

We know the devastating impact the Senate GOP bill would have on Americans across the country. But how would it impact you and your family specifically? The Kaiser Family Foundation has a tool to help you figure that out.  For example: A 60-year-old making $30,000 in Riverside Country would see their premiums for a bronze plan increase by a stunning 507%.

Last week at a House Veterans Committee hearing, I asked representatives from the VFW, the American Legion, and the Paralyzed Veterans of America how important it is to fill the nearly 50,000 open jobs at the VA, including roughly 40,000 at the Veterans Health Administration. Edith Windsor grew up in a world that was unwilling to accept her identity. Three years ago, 1,700 workers across four Walmart-owned warehouses in Mira Loma won a $22 million settlement after years of alleged wage theft. That settlement was only possible because – although Walmart did not directly run the warehouse – the company’s ability to control the warehouse made them responsible for the treatment of its workers.   The legal term for this is "joint employer." The joint employer standard has remained unchanged for decades and helps prevent large companies like Walmart from outsourcing accountability for the laws that protect workers’ wages and ensure their right to collectively bargain for better working conditions.   At a hearing this morning, House Republicans discussed their plan to weaken the joint employer standard to such an extreme that workers would no longer have this protection. Under the bill they’ve introduced, Walmart would not have been responsible for the rights of the Mira Loma warehouse workers, and those workers would not have had the ability to recover stolen wages.   As I said during the hearing, America’s extreme income inequality is proof that our economy is rigged against the average American worker. Repealing the joint employer standard would make this problem worse by stripping workers of what little leverage they have left.   I will continue to strongly oppose this bill.

Today we say thank you to America’s veterans and remember that, as civilians, we have a mission of our own.   First, we must provide veterans and their families the care and support they earned through their service. Whether its access to health care, access to benefits, or access to economic opportunity, it is our duty to keep the promises we’ve made.   Second, we must separate the honor of service from the truth of combat. While we completely and unreservedly support the men and women who have the courage to fight, we also recognize the incalculable toll that war has on those who serve, on their families, on their communities, and on our country.   And finally, we must accept that – while the veterans among us today have experienced things that many of us can never truly understand – it is our duty to try. The feeling of isolation that many veterans feel after their service is not on them to solve. It is on us to build a community, a culture, and a country that seeks to appreciate, understand, and honor their sacrifices.   Thank you to all who served. We will never forget you.  #VeteransDay
